channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Journalists and Dissidents Freed in Prisoner Exchange With Russia
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, and about two dozen other people were freed as part of a deal whose scope has little precedent in the post-Soviet era. President Biden said “their brutal ordeal is over.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dan Lyon/Agence France-Presse, via Wall Street Journal
item.media:description: Wall Street Journal Editor-in-Chief Emma Tucker reacts to the release of reporter Evan Gershkovich, in the Wall Street Journal newsroom on Thursday.

item.title: How Hamas Leader Ismail Haniyeh Was Killed in Iran
item.description: An explosive device hidden in a heavily guarded complex where Ismail Haniyeh was known to stay in Iran was what killed him, according to a Times investigation.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Israel Claims Killing of Militant Leader as Funerals Are Held for 2 Others
item.description: The fate of Muhammad Deif, a top Hamas leader, has been unclear, and the group has not confirmed his death. Funerals for senior officials from Hamas and Hezbollah, both of whom were assassinated this week, drew thousands.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters

item.title: Fears of Wider Mideast Conflict Deepen, With U.S. Seen as ‘Not in Control’
item.description: American officials said they had no advance warning of the attack on the Hamas leader in Iran, raising worries of a power vacuum that could lead to a broader geopolitical crisis.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People in Tehran on Wednesday held Iranian and Palestinian flags and images of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas leader who was killed in the city that morning.

item.title: How Track’s Athletics Integrity Unit Catches Doping Cheats
item.description: Track and field’s antidoping arm, the Athletics Integrity Unit, has announced a string of cases in recent months. Is that the sign of a problem, or proof that its approach is working?
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Violette Franchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Capdevielle, left, head of testing at the Athletics Integrity Unit, and Brett Clothier, the organization’s chief executive, at their offices in Monaco. “We don’t catch everyone,” Mr. Clothier said. “There’s no questions about that.”

item.title: Can Gouda’s Cheesemakers Stall a Sinking Future?
item.description: The small city where the renowned Dutch cheese is made is subsiding as sea levels rise. Experts say the industry may not survive there, even with the ingenuity of the country’s water managers.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ad van Kluijve selling his cheeses at the weekly market in Gouda, the Netherlands.

item.title: Unrest at Israeli Army Bases Highlights Battle for Country’s Soul
item.description: After Israeli soldiers were detained on suspicion of abusing a Palestinian, riots broke out that symbolize a wider struggle over Israel’s future that has divided the country.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Natan Odenheimer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Right-wing protesters demonstrate against the arrest of Israeli soldiers at Beit Lid military base, Israel.

item.title: More Ukrainians Appear Open to a Peace Deal
item.description: Most Ukrainians still oppose ceding any territory to Russia. But polls and recent remarks by the country’s leaders highlight a palpable shift in the conversation around peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Predchenko, right, and her mother, Kateryna Predchenko, looking at the makeshift memorial for fallen soldiers at Maidan Square in Kyiv last week.

item.title: Drone Strike in Sudan Targets Army Leader in Failed Assassination Attempt, Military Says
item.description: For 15 months, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan has been leading a war for control of the country against his rival, Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, the head of the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, center, during a graduation ceremony in Gebeit near Port Sudan on Wednesday.

item.title: Election Results Presented by Venezuela’s Opposition Suggest Maduro Lost Decisively
item.description: The Times analyzed partial voting tallies collected by the opposition. They cast further doubt on Nicolás Maduro’s declared victory.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ethan Singer
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waited outside a polling station for the announcement of results in the election on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Ismail Haniyeh, a Top Hamas Leader, Is Dead at 62
item.description: Mr. Haniyeh, the Palestinian militant group’s exiled political chief, managed high-stakes negotiations, including the ongoing cease-fire talks to end the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader, was in Tehran on Tuesday for the inauguration ceremony of Iran’s new president.

item.title: Guinea Court Finds Former President Guilty of Stadium Massacre and Rapes
item.description: The West African nation’s former leader and some of his top aides were found guilty of crimes against humanity for mass murder and rapes committed during and after a pro-democracy protest in 2009.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Abdourahmane Diallo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Ahmed Ouoba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Guinea’s former president, Capt. Moussa Dadis Camara, at a news conference in 2015.

item.title: Pro-Democracy Organization Denounces Venezuela’s Election
item.description: The Carter Center, a leading pro-democracy organization, says Venezuela’s election violated the country’s own laws and was undemocratic.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up to vote on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Venezuela’s Election Was Deeply Flawed. Here’s How.
item.description: From voter intimidation to refusing to provide paper tallies to verify the result claimed by the government, the election was riddled with problems.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poll workers during the election on Sunday in Caracas, Venezuela’s capital.

item.title: Israel Confirms Death of Muhammad Deif, Who It Says Helped Planned Hamas Attack
item.description: The Israeli military said it had killed Muhammad Deif, who it called a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Farnaz Fassihi, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Thursday carried the coffin of a commander, Fuad Shukr, who was killed in an Israeli airstrike in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

item.title: Katie Ledecky’s 13th Olympic medal is a silver, but one for the record books.
item.description: No female American Olympian has won more medals than Ledecky, who swam the third leg for the Americans’ 4x200 freestyle relay team that finished second behind Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, James Hill and Karen Hanley
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Friday Briefing: Evan Gershkovich Freed in a Prisoner Swap
item.description: Plus, how a Hamas leader was assassinated in Iran and a look inside the Olympic Village.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Russian Federal Security Service/RTR, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich on a plane leaving Russia, in an image from video footage provided by the Russian Federal Security Service.

item.title: Vault + bars + beam + floor = gold for Simone Biles.
item.description: Here’s a look at how Simone Biles won the gymnastics all-around gold medal, one routine at a time.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor, Gabriela Bhaskar, Chang W. Lee and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times

item.title: Evan Gershkovich and 23 Others Freed From Russian Prisons in Major Swap
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich was among 24 people released in a seven-nation, painstakingly negotiated deal that President Biden hailed as a triumph of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in Yekaterinburg, Russia, in June.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich Was Caught in Oppression His Parents Had Fled
item.description: Evan Gershkovich was raised in New Jersey by parents who left the Soviet Union to escape antisemitism and a lack of opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich inside an enclosure for defendants before a court hearing in June in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: Turkey Revels in the Role It Played in Prisoner Swap
item.description: Turkey has frustrated its NATO allies by often refusing to get tough with Russia, but its good relations with Moscow may have helped it participate in the exchange.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Serdar Ozsoy/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Russian plane leaving Ankara Esenboga Airport in Ankara, Turkey, after a major prisoner exchange between Russia, the United States and other countries on Thursday.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Threatens Retaliation Against Israel After Airstrike Near Beirut
item.description: Nasrallah delivered a televised address at the funeral of a Hezbollah commander who was killed in an Israeli strike in suburban Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, seen on a video screen at the funeral for Fuad Shukr, a Hezbollah commander, in Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: Pakistanis Rise Up Against Ruling Elite as Misery Multiplies
item.description: Unrest over a range of economic and security issues threatens to deepen the political turmoil that has plagued Pakistan for years.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Rahat Dar/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A protest against higher electricity bills in Karachi, Pakistan, in July.

item.title: Who Is Vadim Krasikov, the Russian Exchanged for a U.S. Reporter?
item.description: Vadim Krasikov was sentenced to life in prison in Germany for a brazen assassination in a downtown park in Berlin. Now he is free.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Berlin police department
item.media:description: A photo distributed by the Berlin police showed the primary suspect in the assassination of a former Chechen separatist fighter. He carried a passport identifying himself as Vadim A. Sokolov. He was later identified as Vadim N. Krasikov,

item.title: How Golf and Physics Are Raising the Limits in Shot-Put
item.description: Ryan Crouser, an American, has combined radar technology borrowed from golf and an innovative technique to take aim at his third straight Olympic gold.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Patrick Smith/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ryan Crouser at the U.S. track and field trials in June. He holds the world record in the shot-put.

item.title: Turkey Aims to Cull Its Stray Dogs. Critics Say It’s About Politics.
item.description: Turkey’s new law aimed at moving millions of stray dogs to shelters, and allowing some to be euthanized, has both cultural and political implications.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Yasin Akgul/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A stray dog resting in front of Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, in May.

item.title: Who Was Freed in the Prisoner Swap Between Russia and the West?
item.description: Here’s a list of the 24 prisoners who were exchanged on Thursday and their backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Italian Boxer Angela Carini Quits Olympic Bout, Sparking Gender Furor
item.description: The Italian, Angela Carini, stopped fighting only 46 seconds into her matchup against Imane Khelif of Algeria, who had been barred from a women’s event last year.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Yahya Arhab/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Imane Khelif of Algeria is declared the winner after Angela Carini of Italy abandoned their Olympic boxing match in Paris.

item.title: Who Are the Most Prominent People Released in the Russia Prisoner Swap?
item.description: The prisoners released on Thursday include a Wall Street Journal reporter, an editor working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and a former U.S. Marine who had served in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich stood in a glass defendants’ cage before a hearing in June.

item.title: Sprouts Spotted by the Stump of the Sycamore Gap Tree
item.description: Vandals last year chopped down the famed tree, which had stood on Hadrian’s Wall in England for nearly 200 years.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Jason Lock/National Trust
item.media:description: The Sycamore Gap tree, a beloved way marker, had grown for centuries along Hadrian’s Wall in England before vandals cut it down last year. Now little shoots have been discovered growing at its stump.

item.title: Famine Declared in Darfur Region of Sudan
item.description: Experts who monitor global hunger rarely make an official declaration of famine, but they just sounded the alarm for more than half a million people who have fled the fighting in Sudan’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Mohamed Zakaria/Reuters
item.media:description: Women and children at the Zamzam displacement camp, close to El Fasher in North Darfur, Sudan, in January.

item.title: South Korea Offers Humanitarian Aid to Flood-Stricken North Korea
item.description: If accepted, the help could lead to the first official dialogue in years between the two Koreas, which have recently been sending each other trash balloons and propaganda.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media shows flooding in the city of Sinuiju, North Korea, on Sunday.

item.title: Suspect in Southport Stabbings Is Named
item.description: A judge allowed the naming of the 17-year-old charged with murder, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer vowed a crackdown on riots fueled by far-right misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Benjamin Cremel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters remonstrate with police officers during a demonstration on Whitehall, outside the entrance to Downing Street in central London on July 31.

item.title: Security Concerns Grow for Israeli Olympians in Paris
item.description: Concerns for the Israeli team — which has been shrouded in protection at every Games since 1972 — have substantially increased since the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks and the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security officers before a soccer game last week at the Olympics in Paris.

item.title: Elon Musk Blasts Venezuela’s Maduro in an Escalating War of Words
item.description: Mr. Musk, who has long criticized leftist politicians, called President Nicolás Maduro a “dictator” and compared him to a donkey.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Let’s go for it, Elon Musk,” said President Nicolás Maduro, shown on Wednesday during a news conference in Caracas.

item.title: As Botanists Drop a Racist Plant Name, Some Fear Scientific Confusion
item.description: The International Botanical Congress voted to change a scientific name belonging to hundreds of plant species because it was offensive in southern Africa.
item.dc:creator: Clarissa Brincat
item.media:credit: Alamy

item.title: Like Cyclists in a Peloton, Schooling Fish Save Energy, Study Finds
item.description: Like Olympic cyclists, fish expend less effort when swimming in tight groups than when alone. The finding could explain why some species evolved to move in schools.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: How Olympic Injuries Break Bodies
item.description: With years of fractures, surgeries, hardware and pain, Olympians can list their injuries as readily as their achievements.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariana Pajón, a Colombian BMX rider, showing a scar from among her many surgeries.

item.title: Muhammad Deif, a Top Hamas Commander, Is Dead, Israel Says
item.description: Mr. Deif has survived several previous Israeli assassination attempts and has been the No. 2 Hamas leader in Gaza. Israel said it killed him in a strike last month in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: For Simone Biles, a Long Road Back Is Paved in Gold
item.description: After winning the all-around gymnastics title, she wore a sparkly necklace in the shape of a goat, for Greatest of All Time. But she is not done yet: She has three more chances to win medals in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Fears of escalation in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professors in Tehran protesting the killing of Ismail Haniyeh.

item.title: In an Italian Village, a Mayor Walks Off the Wine and Everyone Joins In
item.description: Luciano Fregonese, the mayor of a town in Italy known for Prosecco, started walking to counter the calories he consumed at social obligations. His jaunts have become a sensation.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Luciano Fregonese
item.media:description: Luciano Fregonese, center, in a white shirt, on a stroll through the town with his constituents and other walking enthusiasts.

item.title: Nancy Martiny’s Saddles Have a Six-Year Wait Time
item.description: Nancy Martiny’s ornate pieces, which sell for $5,000 and up, are meant to be ridden by working cowboys and cowgirls like herself.
item.dc:creator: Susan Shain and Sasha Arutyunova
item.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: Ex-Green Beret Goudreau, Who Planned Failed Venezuela Coup, Is Arrested
item.description: Jordan Goudreau, 48, had taken credit for a failed coup attempt against Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela. He faces federal charges of illegal arms smuggling.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)

item.title: Iran’s Options for Retaliation Risk Escalating Middle East Crisis
item.description: The killing of Hamas’s political leader in Tehran was a humiliating security failure for the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran during his swearing-in ceremony in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Assassination of a top Hamas leader spurs rallies worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Iran and Hamas Blame Israel for Killing of Ismail Haniyeh, and Vow Revenge
item.description: The deadly strike on Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran threatened to further inflame the region and derail negotiations aimed at reaching a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying Palestinian flags and chanting “death to Israel” in Tehran on Wednesday, in protest over the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a Hamas leader.

item.title: See the Moment Katie Ledecky Won Gold in the 1500-Meter Freestyle
item.description: Katie Ledecky comfortably won the 1,500-meter freestyle, beating her winning time from the Tokyo Games by more than seven seconds.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Chang W. Lee and James Hill
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Two Al Jazeera Journalists Were Killed in an Israeli Strike on Gaza
item.description: A reporter and a cameraman were working from or near the house of Ismail Haniyeh, the Hamas political chief who was assassinated on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ayman Al Hassi/Reuters
item.media:description: Palestinians inspect a vehicle where Al Jazeera TV said its reporter Ismail al-Ghoul and cameraman Ramy El Rify were killed in an Israeli strike, in Gaza City July 31, 2024.

item.title: Iran’s Leader Orders Attack on Israel for Haniyeh Killing, Officials Say
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, ordered retaliation after a humiliating security failure, as Iran once again balances showing strength against the risk of escalation.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of Ismail Haniyeh, a senior Hamas leader who was assassinated in Iran on Wednesday, at a square in Tehran.

item.title: How Henrik Christiansen Made Chocolate Muffins a Hit at the Olympics
item.description: On a quest to fuel himself with thousands of calories a day, Henrik Christiansen found an unexpected delight and shared it with the world.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Henrik Christiansen
item.media:description: The muffins on offer inside the cafeteria at the Olympic Village, in Saint-Denis.

item.title: Robot Captures Pictures of the Dotson Ice Shelf in Antarctica
item.description: The new images of the melting underside of an ice shelf could help scientists better forecast how the continent is contributing to rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: ‘20th Hijacker’ Is Denied Transfer From Federal Supermax to French Prison
item.description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person to be convicted in connection with the 9/11 attacks, had requested to serve the rest of his life sentence in his native country instead of a prison in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Andrew Miller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The supermax prison in Florence, Colo., where Zacarias Moussaoui is serving his life sentence.

item.title: How Will a Hamas Leader’s Killing Affect Gaza Cease-Fire Talks?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was assassinated in Iran, was a key figure in Hamas’s cease-fire negotiations with Israel and his assassination makes the prospects for a deal even more unclear.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israelis in Tel Aviv marked nine months in July since the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas.

item.title: After Haniyeh’s Death, Who Are Hamas’s Most Prominent Leaders?
item.description: Ismail Haniyeh, who was killed in Iran, was among the most senior members of Hamas’s leadership. Here is a look at others.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, head of the political bureau of Hamas, delivering a speech in 2023 in Gaza City.

item.title: Alex Yee overcomes currents, heat and a big deficit to pull of a dramatic comeback.
item.description: Alex Yee overcame a big deficit to pull off a dramatic comeback to win the men’s race.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Strikes in Iran and Lebanon Raise Risk of Escalation, but All-Out War Is Not Inevitable
item.description: The scale of the reaction from Iran and its regional proxies to the attacks on two of Israel’s largest foes could determine whether the low-level regional battle tips into a full-scale conflict.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and Hezbollah supporters carrying the coffins of Amira, 6, and her brother Hassan Fadlallah, 10, who were killed in an Israeli airstrike in Dahiyeh, a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Iceland Warns of Volcanic Eruption ‘In the Coming Days’
item.description: The Icelandic Meteorological Office has warned of an eruption “in the coming days.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: John Moore/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Sundhnukur volcano erupting on the Reykjanes Peninsula near Grindavik, Iceland, in June. The volcano, which has erupted five times since December, has forced the evacuation of the fishing village of Grindavik as well as the nearby Blue Lagoon geothermal spa.

item.title: Disinformation Fed Far-Right Riot in England After Deadly Stabbing
item.description: More than 50 police were injured in an outbreak of violence driven by false reports that the suspect in the stabbing attack on a children’s dance class was a migrant.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Getty Images/Getty Images
item.media:description: Riot police officers holding back protesters in Southport, England, on Tuesday.

item.title: Paris Olympics: Why Gymnast Kaylia Nemour Is Competing for Algeria, Not France
item.description: A bitter fight with the French gymnastics federation threatened the Olympic hopes of Kaylia Nemour. Dual nationality offered a way out.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle and James Hill
item.media:description: Kaylia Nemour, with hands on hips, at a gym in Avoine, western France. She is a medal favorite in the uneven bars.

item.title: Haniyeh’s Death Will Shake but Not Destroy Hamas, Analysts Say
item.description: Hamas will need to scramble to replace Ismail Haniyeh following his killing in Tehran, analysts say, but the group has recovered from past assassinations of its political and military leaders.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ismail Haniyeh, center, in Gaza City in 2012. Mr. Haniyeh was one of Hamas’s most recognizable faces worldwide.

item.title: India’s Deadly Landslides, Explained
item.description: The death toll has steadily risen in Kerala state after heavy rain sent huge mudslides through a scenic area known as a tourist destination.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das, Pragati K.B. and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Idrees Mohammed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tea plantation workers heading to a relief camp after landslides in Kerala, India, on Wednesday.
